channel.title: MacOS - Today I Learnt...
channel.description: Recent content in MacOS on Today I Learnt...

item.title: That macOS Ventura and iOS 15 can play background rain noise
item.description: For years, I’ve been using https://rain.today for background rain noise, but I recently discovered that macOS Ventura and iOS 15 can play rain noise too.

item.title: How to easily copy annotated screenshots to the clipboard on macOS
item.description: I frequently want to take screenshots, annotate them, then paste the marked up image into an application like Slack or Github; I don’t want to save a file to the ~/Desktop.

item.title: The names for macOS keyboard meta-characters
item.description: You can insert a ⌘ character using the Character Viewer pop-up.

item.title: About Chrome's named windows
item.description: Since Google Chrome v88 (Jan 2021), browser windows can be given a name via the .

item.title: iTerm2's "Cursor boost" feature will cause everything to appear dimmed
item.description: I had inadvertently moved the “Cursor Boost” slider to a high level and the terminal became very dim and hard to read.

item.title: How to scroll horizontally with a mouse
item.description: If you hold shift while using the mouse wheel then you can scroll horizontally.

item.title: How temporary files are removed on MacOS
item.description: On MacOS, temporary files are stored in either /tmp/ or a per-user temporary folder specified by the $TMPDIR environment variable; this is normally a subfolder of /var/folders/.

item.title: About the difference between minimising and hiding windows in MacOS
item.description: Minimising: ⌘ + m minimises the active application window.

item.title: The MacOS keybinds for en- and em-dashes
item.description: Which are: alt + - for an en-dash (–); shift + alt + - for an em-dash (—); You can always get them from the ctrl + cmd + space character picker but good to know quicker alternatives.

item.title: About the stationery pad feature in Finder
item.description: If you use Finder to mark a file as a “stationery pad” then apps will open a copy of the file.

item.title: About Quitter
item.description: There’s a MacOS app called Quitter which will automatically quit applications after some period of inactivity.
